headline.main: Should Charities Focus More on America?

docs.abstract: Do you think American charities direct too much attention and funding abroad?
docs.snippet: Do you think American charities direct too much attention and funding abroad?

byline.original: By DANIEL E. SLOTNIK and HOLLY EPSTEIN OJALVO

docs.lead_paragraph: Have you ever wondered why some charities seem focused more on international issues than those in America? Do you think focusing predominantly on other countries is fair? If you ran a large charity, where would you direct your funds? Why?

headline.main: Should Charities Focus More on America?

docs.abstract: Do you think American charities direct too much attention and funding abroad?
docs.snippet: Do you think American charities direct too much attention and funding abroad?

byline.original: By DANIEL E. SLOTNIK and HOLLY EPSTEIN OJALVO

docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration ordered a health insurance company to rescind the rate increases it sought or justify its refusal to do so.

headline.seo: White House Calls Increases in Health Insurance Rates Too High
headline.main: U.S. Seeks Rollback of a Health Insurer’s ‘Excessive’ Rate Increase
headline.print_headline: U.S. Seeks Rollback of a Health Insurer’s ‘Excessive’ Rate Increase

docs.abstract: Obama administration says that rate increases sought by a health insurance company are unreasonable and orders the insurer to rescind them or justify its refusal to do so; Kathleen Sebelius, secretary of health and human services, issued the finding against the carrier, Trustmark Life Insurance Company, a unit of Trustmark Mutual Holding Company.
docs.snippet: The Obama administration ordered a health insurance company to rescind the rate increases it sought or justify its refusal to do so.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: President Dilma Rousseff has ordered the public health system and health insurance companies to pay for the replacement of ruptured breast implants made in France, reversing an earlier government position.

headline.main: Brazil: Government Will Pay to Replace Ruptured Implants
headline.print_headline: Brazil: Government Will Pay To Replace Ruptured Implants

docs.abstract: Brazilian Pres Dilma Rousseff orders the public health system and health insurance companies to pay for the replacement of ruptured breast implants made in France, even if they were implanted for aesthetic reasons.
docs.snippet: President Dilma Rousseff has ordered the public health system and health insurance companies to pay for the replacement of ruptured breast implants made in France, reversing an earlier government position.

headline.main: In the Fight Against Poverty, It's Time for a Revolution

docs.abstract: With poverty in America deepening, the need for committed programs like LIFT is urgent.
docs.snippet: With poverty in America deepening, the need for committed programs like LIFT is urgent.

docs.lead_paragraph: Is it time to rethink our basic assumptions about the way we fight poverty?

headline.main: In the Fight Against Poverty, It's Time for a Revolution

docs.abstract: With poverty in America deepening, the need for committed programs like LIFT has grown more urgent.
docs.snippet: With poverty in America deepening, the need for committed programs like LIFT has grown more urgent.

headline.main: Update to my Previous Post on Truth Vigilantes

docs.abstract: An update provided by the public editor on his earlier post, followed by a response from Times executive editor Jill Abramson.
docs.snippet: An update provided by the public editor on his earlier post, followed by a response from Times executive editor Jill Abramson.

docs.lead_paragraph: I have appended a statement from Jill Abramson, the executive editor, responding to this post.

headline.main: Update to my Previous Post on Truth Vigilantes

docs.abstract: An update provided by the public editor on his earlier post, followed by a response from Times executive editor Jill Abramson.
docs.snippet: An update provided by the public editor on his earlier post, followed by a response from Times executive editor Jill Abramson.

docs.lead_paragraph: It’s too early to know whether the trend of slower growth will persist after the economy improves, but controlling spending will require reforms.
docs.abstract: Editorial contends that it is too earlier to decide whether reduced growth in United States health care spending in 2010 is due to increased system efficiency or the economic recession; notes bigger changes are in store in 2014 when expanded Medicaid takes effect under health care reform law.
docs.snippet: It’s too early to know whether the trend of slower growth will persist after the economy improves, but controlling spending will require reforms.

docs.lead_paragraph: Don’t worry, people! With the South Carolina primary coming up next, here are the answers to the most important questions that are surely on your mind.
docs.abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column answers series of humorous questions related to the Republican presidential candidates as they move on to the South Carolina primary.
docs.snippet: Don’t worry, people! With the South Carolina primary coming up next, here are the answers to the most important questions that are surely on your mind.
